label: SMU ID
definition: Alphanumeric ID number for stock management unit (SMU) demographic unit. An official list of SMU ID's and corresponding names can be found in the SMU/CU crosswalk in NuSEDS

label: Species
definition: Fish species vernacular name. Permissible values are salmoniod or trout species as listed in bioportal salmon ontology

label: Start Year
definition: The start year the salmon unit (i.e., population, CU, SMU, PMFA) became active. Generally active unit's are labelled as current.

label: End Year
definition: The year the unit (i.e., population, CU, SMU, PMFA) ends being active.

label: Data Collection Methods
definition: Notes on data collection methds (data sources, type of count) that apply to the entire timeseries. 1-2 sentences from the authors

label: Data Analysis Methods
definition: Notes on data analysis (infill methods, analytical framework) that apply to the entire timeseries. 1-2 sentences from the authors

label: Year Method
definition: The type of year definition that is used in the timeseries (ex: return year, catch year, brood year)
method: The aim of this column will be to eventually develop categorical variables for this data type after looking at common types from authors

label: Age Method
definition: The type of age definition that is used in the timeseries(ex: Gilbert-Rich, European)

label: Information Quality
definition_uri: Odgen et al. 2015, Productivity (Recruits-per-Spawner) Data for Sockeye, Pink, and Chum Salmon from British Columbia
definition: Quality of the dataset quantified from 1-5 based on the data quality framework in Ogden 2015, section 2.3

label: Limit Reference Point
definition: The limit reference point (LRP)represents the stock status, usually in terms of biomass (or abundance), below which serious to the stock may be incurred. In Canada and elsewhere, serious harm is considered to include recruitment overfishing or other impairment to productive capacity. When the stock falls below LRP, urgent management actions are required to rebuild the population and prevent further depletion. It represents the minimum level needed to sustain a fish population over time. Under the Fish Stocks provisions, the LRP is determined solely by DFO Science based on biological considerations.
method: Limit reference point, preference to display one table for all reference points below

label: Upper Stock Reference
definition: The upper stock reference (USR) is to serves as a threshold to progressive reduction of the fishing mortality rate to avoid stock status reaching the LRP. The USR is also assigned the role of delineating the threshold between what are termed the Cautious and Healthy Zones. When stock levels are above USR, they are considered healthy. However, if they drop below the USR but remain above the LRP, the stock enters the cautious zone, signaling a need for more conservative management measures to prevent further decline.
method: Upper stock reference point if known

label: Target Reference
definition: A management target reference point that represents a desired stock or exploitation level, often based on social, economic, and ecological considerations, in addition to biological ones.

label: Removal Reference
definition: Removal Reference (RR) represents the maximum proportion of the population that can be harvested without jeopardizing the stock's ability to replenish itself. It can be expressed in terms of Fishing mortality, Harvest rate or Fishing effort.

label: Coded Wire Tagging
definition: Refer to specific metrics or data derived from coded wire tags (CWTs) (like survival or exploitation rates). NA if no CWT was used

label: Reference
definition: Plain text reference for the report that the data was published or archived in.

label: Contact
definition: Name and email contact for a data steward or expert who is the correspondant for the dataset

label: Comments
definition: Additional comments about the time series from the authors.

label: Year
definition: The year measurements were captured (please see YEAR_TYPE)

label: Mainstem (Age 1)
definition: Number of fish caught in mainstem at age 1.

label: Mainstem (Age 2)
definition: Number of fish caught in mainstem at age 2.

label: Maintsem (Age 3)
definition: Number of fish caught in mainstem at age 3.

label: Maintsem (Age 4)
definition: Number of fish caught in mainstem at age 4.

label: Maintsem (Age 5)
definition: Number of fish caught in mainstem at age 5.

label: Maintsem (Age 6)
definition: Number of fish caught in mainstem at age 6.

label: Maintsem (Age 7)
definition: Number of fish caught in mainstem at age 7.

label: Mainstem Mortality Rate
definition: The proportion of fish that die while migrating through the mainstem of a river system, which is typically the primary, large river channel. It reduces the number of fish reaching their spawning ground.

label: Ocean (Age 1)
definition: Number of fish caught in ocean at age 1.

label: Ocean (Age 2)
definition: Number of fish caught in ocean at age 2.

label: Ocean (Age 3)
definition: Number of fish caught in ocean at age 3.

label: Ocean (Age 4)
definition: Number of fish caught in ocean at age 4.

label: Ocean (Age 5)
definition: Number of fish caught in ocean at age 5.

label: Ocean (Age 6)
definition: Number of fish caught in ocean at age 6.

label: Ocean (Age 7)
definition: Number of fish caught in ocean at age 7.

label: Ocean Mortality Rate
definition: The proportion of fish that die while at sea, due to natural causes such as predation, disease, starvation, or unfavorable environmental conditions. It affects overall survival before returning to rivers

label: Terminal (Age 1)
definition: Number of fish caught in terminal at age 1.

label: Terminal (Age 2)
definition: Number of fish caught in terminal at age 2.

label: Terminal (Age 3)
definition: Number of fish caught in terminal at age 3.

label: Terminal (Age 4)
definition: Number of fish caught in terminal at age 4.

label: Terminal (Age 5)
definition: Number of fish caught in terminal at age 5.

label: Terminal (Age 6)
definition: Number of fish caught in terminal at age 6.

label: Terminal (Age 7)
definition: Number of fish caught in terminal at age 7.

label: Terminal Mortality Rate
definition: The proportion of fish that die in the terminal area (near or at their spawning grounds) before they can spawn. Terminal areas are typically in rivers or estuaries. This rate affects the spawning population and recruitment success, directly impacting the stock's ability to replenish.

label: Spawners (Age 1)
definition: Number of age 1 spawners.

label: Spawners (Age 2)
definition: Number of age 2 spawners.

label: Spawners (Age 3)
definition: Number of age 3 spawners.

label: Spawners (Age 4)
definition: Number of age 4 spawners.

label: Spawners (Age 5)
definition: Number of age 5 spawners.

label: Spawners (Age 6)
definition: Number of age 6 spawners.

label: Spawners (Age 7)
definition: Number of age 7 spawners.

label: Total Spawners
definition: Total number of spawners for the year.

label: Total Catch
definition: This includes harvest numbers from commercial, recreational, and First Nations fisheries.

label: Total Mortality
definition: Thee proportion of a population that dies during a specific time period, regardless of the cause.

label: Total Exploitation
definition: The proportion of a fish population that is harvested or removed through fishing activities in a given period, typically over a season or year. It is expressed as a percentage of the total population or run size of the species being managed.

label: CU ID
definition: Alphanumeric ID number for conservation unit (CU) demographic unit. An official list of CU ID's and corresponding names can be found in the SMU/CU crosswalk in NuSEDS

label: Lower CI Lower Limit
definition: The lower bound of the confidence interval (CI) for the lower limit of a stock-related metric.

label: Uper CI Lower Limit
definition: The lower bound of the confidence interval (CI) for the upper limit of a stock-related metric.

label: Lower CI Upper Limit
definition: The upper bound of the confidence interval (CI) for the lower limit of a stock-related metric.

label: Upper CI Upper Limit
definition: The upper bound of the confidence interval (CI) for the upper limit of a stock-related metric.

label: Lower Range CI
definition: The lower range of a Confidence Interval (CI)

label: Upper Ranger CI
definition: The upper range of a Confidence Interval (CI)

label: PFMA ID
definition: Numeric ID corresponding to a Pacific Fishery Management Area (PFMA). PFMA's are a division of Canadian fisheries waters as enumerated and described in Schedule 2 and includes the portion of any stream that flows into that division and that is seaward of the mean high water mark near the mouth of that stream. The areas in the Canadian fisheries waters of the Pacific Ocean described in Schedule 2 are hereby prescribed as management areas.

label: Upper Management Level
definition: Upper reference point for the PFMA

label: Lower Management Level
definition: Mgmt Level - can represent either escapement targets or inflection points on HCR or removal reference for the PFMA

label: Population ID
definition: Numeric code identifying the population

label: Enhancement Objective
definition: The specific goal or purpose of a fish enhancement program, often aimed at increasing the productivity, survival, or abundance of a fish population to support conservation, fisheries, or ecosystem needs.

label: Enhancement Target
definition: A quantitative or qualitative benchmark set within an enhancement program that defines the desired outcome, such as the number of fish released, survival rates, or spawner returns.

label: Marine Survival Index
definition: A measure or metric used to evaluate the survival rate of fish during their time in the ocean, often expressed as a percentage of juveniles that survive to return as adults.

label: Expansion Factor
definition: Expansion factor for run reconstruction if catch at PFMA, is a tool to estimate the total run size of fish in a specific Pacific Fisheries Management Area, scaling up from observed catch numbers to account for unobserved components of the population.

label: Enhanced
definition: Boolean response to if the population is enhanced (Y/N/NA)

label: Proportion Hatchery Origin Spawners
definition_uri: Genetically based targets for enhanced contributions to Canadian Pacific chinook salmon populations / Withler, R. [et al.].: Fs70-5/2018-019E-PDF - Government of Canada Publications - Canada.ca
definition: The proportion of hatchery-origin spawners

label: Recruits
definition: The number of juvenile fish (recruits) that survive to join the adult population, crucial for understanding population dynamics. Recruitment is typically inferred from the number of spawners, environmental conditions, and population dynamics models. It is not measured directly by test fisheries or spawner surveys. Instead, recruitment is estimated using spawner-recruit models, which predict future population sizes based on the number of spawners, environmental conditions, and historical data.

label: Total Broodstock Removed
definition: Refers to the number of fish that are deliberately taken from a population, typically from a river or hatchery, to be used as broodstock for artificial propagation in hatcheries or other enhancement programs.

label: Hatchery Origin Broodstock
definition_uri: Genetically based targets for enhanced contributions to Canadian Pacific chinook salmon populations / Withler, R. [et al.].: Fs70-5/2018-019E-PDF - Government of Canada Publications - Canada.ca
definition: Refers to broodstock fish that were born or reared in a hatchery and later selected for breeding purposes within the hatchery system., It's also called "Enhanced Salmon", originating from hatchery production.

label: Natural Origin Broodstock
definition: Refers to broodstock fish that are born and reared in the wild (natural environment) but are later collected and used in hatchery breeding programs.
